content: The "Nuclear Terrorism Prevention Act of 2006" may be cited as the short title. Definitions are provided in Section 2 of the Act. The "Nuclear Terrorism Prevention Act of 2006" defines key terms such as the Convention on the Physical Protection of Nuclear Material, design-basis threat, and formula quantities of strategic special nuclear material. The "Nuclear Terrorism Prevention Act of 2006" defines terms like the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and nuclear weapons as devices using atomic energy for weapon purposes. SEC. 3. FINDINGS. Congress finds that the threat of terrorists acquiring and using a nuclear weapon is urgent and poses a significant risk to national and global security. Efforts to secure nuclear stockpiles and prevent nuclear terrorism have made progress, but additional measures are necessary to further reduce this threat. The White House's 2006 National Strategy for Combating Terrorism highlights the grave danger of weapons of mass destruction in the hands of terrorists, and the United Nations Secretary-General has warned about the catastrophic impact of a nuclear terror attack. United Nations Security Council Resolution 1540 (2004) emphasizes the need to prevent non-state actors from acquiring and using nuclear, chemical, or biological weapons for terrorist purposes. It directs countries to adopt and enforce laws prohibiting these activities to maintain international peace and security. The Director General of the International Atomic Energy Agency warns of the urgent need to prevent terrorist attacks using nuclear weapons. SEC. 4. SENSE OF CONGRESS ON THE PREVENTION OF NUCLEAR TERRORISM. The sense of Congress is that the threat of nuclear terror is the most horrific the United States faces. A comprehensive approach is needed to reduce this danger, including efforts to eliminate terrorist groups seeking nuclear weapons, secure nuclear weapons worldwide, and prevent terrorist efforts to manufacture or transport nuclear explosives. The President must prioritize preventing nuclear terrorist attacks and secure nuclear materials worldwide. The International Atomic Energy Agency should be adequately funded to coordinate international efforts in protecting nuclear materials. Legislation sponsored by Senator Richard Lugar is crucial in this effort. Legislation sponsored by Senator Richard Lugar, Senator Pete Domenici, and former Senator Sam Nunn has led to groundbreaking programs to prevent nuclear weapons from falling into the hands of terrorists. Senator Richard Lugar, Senator Pete Domenici, and former Senator Sam Nunn sponsored legislation that led to the creation of a new position - Senior Advisor to the President for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism under the National Security Act of 1947. The Senior Advisor to the President for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism, appointed with Senate approval, advises on nuclear terrorism matters and formulates US policies to prevent it by developing plans and addressing program gaps. The Senior Advisor to the President oversees the development of program implementation strategies, budget requests, and new initiatives to prevent nuclear terrorism. They also coordinate US efforts to implement these policies and may appoint necessary personnel. Additionally, the Senior Advisor is a member of the National Security Council. The Senior Advisor to the President for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism is added as a new paragraph in the Act, with amendments to paragraph (6) and redesignation of paragraph (7). The Senior Advisor oversees program strategies, budget requests, and initiatives to prevent nuclear terrorism, coordinating US efforts and being a member of the National Security Council. The Senior Advisor to the President for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism is added as a new paragraph in the Act, overseeing program strategies, budget requests, and initiatives to prevent nuclear terrorism. The President, in consultation with the Senior Advisor for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism, must submit an annual report to Congress on the security of strategic special nuclear material. The report includes details on the program for removal and security of nuclear weapons and materials worldwide. The annual report to Congress includes a list of high-priority sites for securing or removing nuclear weapons and materials, along with a plan for their removal using various means. The annual report to Congress includes a plan for securing nuclear material and related equipment at vulnerable facilities worldwide, efforts to establish security standards, and a requirement for a detailed unclassified summary. SEC. 7 outlines the minimum security standard for nuclear weapons and strategic special nuclear materials. The policy of the United States is to ensure the security and accountability of all nuclear weapons and special nuclear materials. In line with international standards, the President will work towards a global agreement on nuclear security to effectively protect these materials. The President's policy aims to secure nuclear weapons and special nuclear materials globally. Efforts include working with other countries and the International Atomic Energy Agency to upgrade security measures rapidly. The President's policy aims to secure nuclear weapons and special nuclear materials globally by upgrading security measures rapidly and providing financial and technical assistance to countries in need. Additionally, efforts are made to work with other countries to ensure effective nuclear security rules and enforcement worldwide. The President's policy aims to secure nuclear weapons and special nuclear materials globally by upgrading security measures rapidly to defeat threats posed by terrorists and criminals.
